persons.name: Pierre-SimonLaplace
persons.description: French mathematician seen as the Newton of France. He met Davy in 1813 and 1820. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: NapoleonBuonaparte
persons.description: French general and, as First Consul, 1799-1804, and Emperor, 1804-1815, military dictator of France and the territories it occupied. Established the Volta prize for research electricity and provided Davy with a passport to collect it in Paris in 1813.

persons.name: JohnDalton
persons.description: Mancunian chemist and natural philosopher who lectured at the Royal Institution. He formulated a version of the atomic theory of matter much disliked by Davy. FRSL.

places.name: France
places.description: France, officially the French Republic, is a country located primarily in Western Europe.

persons.name: Maria Anna ElisaBonaparte Baciocchi Levoy
persons.description: An imperial French princess and sister of Napoleon Bonaparte. She was Princess of Lucca and Piombino (1805-1814), Grand Duchess of Tuscany (1809-1814) and Countess of Compignano by appointment of her brother. Highly interested in the arts, particularly the theatre, she encouraged them in the territories over which she ruled. An 1812 painting by Benvenuti shows her presiding over artists at her court in Florence.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

persons.name: Claude LouisBerthollet
persons.description: French Chemist. ForMemRSL.

places.name: Florence
places.description: The capital city of the Italian region of Tuscany.

persons.name: Jean-AntoineChaptal
persons.description: French chemist, physician and industrialist. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Pierre-SimonLaplace
persons.description: French mathematician seen as the Newton of France. He met Davy in 1813 and 1820. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Claude LouisBerthollet
persons.description: French Chemist. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: JamesWatt
persons.description: A Scottish scientific instrument maker who studied with the chemist Joseph Black at Glasgow University. He developed the separate condenser for steam engines which increased their effieciency significantly. He took out a twenty-five-year patent (ending in 1800) and moved to Birmingham where he went into partnership with the businessman and industrialist Matthew Boulton. They made their fortune by having an effective monopoly of manufacturing steam engines. A friend of Thomas Beddoes, he met Davy on a number of occasions and Davy gave the oration at the unveiling of Watt's statue in Greenock. FRSL.

persons.name: FrancisHome
persons.description: Physician and Professor of Materia Medica at the University of Edinburgh, 1768-1798.

persons.name: CharlesHatchett
persons.description: He made his money from coach building which he used to pursue his interests in chemistry and mineralogy in the course of which he isolated the chemical element now called niobium. He was a Manager of the Royal Institution, playing a key role especially in running its lecture programme during the 1800s. FRSL.

persons.name: Edward CharlesHoward
persons.description: A brother of the Duke of Norfolk, he became a chemist, discovering the explosive properties of mercury fulminate. FRSL

persons.name: NapoleonBuonaparte
persons.description: French general and, as First Consul, 1799-1804, and Emperor, 1804-1815, military dictator of France and the territories it occupied. Established the Volta prize for research electricity and provided Davy with a passport to collect it in Paris in 1813.

persons.name: MattthewBoulton
persons.description: Birmingham businessman and industrialist who went into partnership with James Watt to manufacture efficient steam engines using Watt's patent for the separate condenser. They made their fortune by having an effective monopoly of manufacturing steam engines until the patent expired in 1800. An early Proprietor of the Royal Institution, he had grave doubts about Rumford's proposal to freely display inventions there. FRSL.

persons.name: Michel EugèneChevreul
persons.description: French organic chemist. Met Davy when he was in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Pierre LouisDulong
persons.description: French physicist and chemist who worked mostly on specific heats, but also discovered nitrogen chloride around the same time as Davy. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: ThomasBeddoes
persons.description: A politically radical (Jacobin) chemist and physician who in the 1790s established the Medical Pneumatic Institution in Bristol to investigate the physiological and possible curative effects of all the gases discovered during the eighteenth century. Between late 1798 and early 1801 he employed Davy as Superintendent of the Institution.

persons.name: RichardKirwan
persons.description: Irish chemist, mineralogist and geologist who accused fellow geologist, James Hutton, of athiesm following publication of his Theory of the Earth (1788). FRSL

persons.name: CharlesBlagden
persons.description: Physician who kept a revealing diary for most of his life. A friend of Joseph Banks serving as a Secretary of the Royal Society of London, 1784-1797; Knighted 1792. FRSL

persons.name: JosephBanks
persons.description: A member of the Lincolnshire gentry, Banks sailed as a botanist on James Cook's first voyage to the Pacific (1768-1771). Elected President of the Royal Society of London in 1778 he served for forty-two years until just before his death. The dominant figure in the running of English science during that time, he became one of Davy's patrons and ultimately Davy succeeded him to the Presidency. FRSL.

persons.name: HenryCavendish
persons.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

persons.name: NevilMaskelyne
persons.description: Astronomer Royal and a Commissioner of the Board of Longitude. Contributed to scientifically measuring the density of the Earth. FRSL.

persons.name: SmithsonTennant
persons.description: Tennant was a botanist and chemist and knew Davy through agricultural improvements. Appointed Professor of Chemistry at Cambridge University in 1813, he was killed in a riding accident on France. FRSL.

persons.name: Louis NicolasVauquelin
persons.description: French pharmacist and chemist who met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: William HydeWollaston
persons.description: Originally a physician he became a prominent chemist, physicist and physiologist isolating the chemical elements osmium, palladium and rhodium. He made his fortune by developing a method of obtaining metallic platinum. A friend and to some extent a rival of Davy's, in 1820 he served briefly as President of the Royal Society of London between Banks's death and Davy's election. FRSL.

persons.name: BenjaminThompson
persons.description: Born in Massachusetts, he served in the British and Bavarian armies. Knighted by George III in 1787, the Elector of Bavaria created him Reichsgraf von Rumford of the Holy Roman Empire in 1792. His appointment in the late 1790s as Bavarian ambassador to London created a minor diplomatic incident, during which he helped establish and manage the Royal Institution, in the course of which he appointed Davy to lecture there. Later he married Lavoisier's widow and lived unhappily ever after. FRSL.

places.name: England
places.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

persons.name: Caroline
persons.description: Of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel who in 1795 married the Prince of Wales (later Prince Regent and George IV. They soon separated causing a series of scandals that lasted until her death. The Davys tended to take her side.

persons.name: DaviesGiddy
persons.description: Changed his surname to Gilbert in 1817. A member of the West Cornwall gentry, he was one of Davy's earliest patrons. A former student of Beddoes at Oxford University, he was a key figure in securing Davy's appointment in 1798 to the Medical Pneumatic Institution. He maintained contact with Davy throughout his life and following his death suceeded Davy as President of the Royal Society of London. FRSL.

persons.name: Louis BernardGuyton de Morveau
persons.description: French chemist and revolutionary politician who is credited with producing the first systematic method of chemical nomenclature. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Siméon DenisPoisson
persons.description: French mathematician and physicist. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: HeinrichOlbers
persons.description: Astronomer who worked in Bremen. He specialised in the detection of asteroids and propounded his eponymous paradox. Davy met him on a visit to Bremen in 1824. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Heinrich ChristianSchumacher
persons.description: Founder and Directort of the Altona astronomical observatory. Davy met him during a visit to Bremen in 1824. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: GeorgesCuvier
persons.description: French naturalist and zoologist who was one of the founders of palaeontology. Perpetual Secretary of the first class of the Institut de France (Académie des Sciences), Davy met him when in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Francis LeggattChantrey
persons.description: Prominent English sculptor who, at the request of Lady Davy, made the memorial plaque to Davy placed in Westminster Abbey. FRSL.

persons.name: WilliamAllen
persons.description: Allen was a Quaker who worked in the pharmaceutical industry. Davy asked him to give lectures on natural philosophy at the RI. FRSL.

persons.name: WilliamHiggins
persons.description: Nephew of Bryan Higgins. Professor of Chemistry at the Dublin Society where he proposed a theory of chemical atomism. Met Davy in London who supported Higgins's claim to the atomic theory over that of John Dalton. FRSL.

persons.name: Gaspard deProny
persons.description: French mathematician and engineer. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: André-MarieAmpère
persons.description: French physicist and mathematician and one of the key figure in the early study of electro-magnetism. Davy met him in Paris in 1813 and they developed a scientific rivalry. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: JohnPlayfair
persons.description: Professor of Natural Philosophy at Edinburgh University. His Illustrations of the Huttonian Theory of the Earth (1802) gave strong support to James Hutton's theory of uniformitarianism. FRSL.

persons.name: TeodoroMonticelli
persons.description: Neapolitan naturalist with an interest in volcanology and the mineralogy of Vesuvius. One of Davy's closest contacts in Naples.

persons.name: Samuel TaylorColeridge
persons.description: Poet and philosopher who met Davy while in Bristol with whom he became a close friend. Suggested that if Davy had not been the first chemist of the age, would have been the first poet.

persons.name: Thomas CharlesHope
persons.description: Professor of Medicine and Chemistry at Edinburgh University. Discovered the element strontium and seems to have played a role in Davy's appointment to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

persons.name: WilliamBuckland
persons.description: Anglican priest who was later Dean of Westminster. Perhaps the last serious geologist to attempt the reconciliation of the findings of contemporary geology with the Biblical accounts. FRSL.

persons.name: JamesHall
persons.description: Scottish baronet (1776) and MP. Chemist and geologist who supported of James Hutton's theories of uniformitarian geology. FRSL.

persons.name: Carl FriedrichGauss
persons.description: Prominent Hanoverian mathematician who was Director of the observatory at Gottingen University. Davy met him during a visit to Bremen in 1824. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: AntonioCanova
persons.description: Italian sculptor and friend of the Davys.

persons.name: RobertSouthey
persons.description: Poet who met Davy in Bristol and included some of his poems in Annual Anthology. Poet Laureate from 1813 until death.

persons.name: George IV
persons.description: Eldest son of George III and Prince of Wales. Served as Prince Regent during the King's madness, 1811-1820, thereafter King of England, Scotland and Ireland. A major patron of the arts, he personally commanded Davy to go to Naples to oversee the unrolling of the Herculaneum papyri. PatronRSL.

persons.name: WilliamWordsworth
persons.description: English poet who, with Samuel Taylor Coleridge, published Lyrical Ballads. Davy contributed to seeing the second edition (1800) through the press in Bristol. Poet Laureate from 1843.

persons.name: WalterScott
persons.description: Scottish poet and novelist. Knew Davy from  1805 when with Wordsworth they together climbed Hellvellyn. Scott was also a distanct cousin of Lady Davy, whom he could not stand.

persons.name: William HydeWollaston
persons.description: Originally a physician he became a prominent chemist, physicist and physiologist isolating the chemical elements osmium, palladium and rhodium. He made his fortune by developing a method of obtaining metallic platinum. A friend and to some extent a rival of Davy's, in 1820 he served briefly as President of the Royal Society of London between Banks's death and Davy's election. FRSL.

persons.name: GeorgeKnox
persons.description: Irish politician who sat in the Dublin and then Westminster parliaments. A collector of minerals, it is not known how he came to know Davy. FRSL.

persons.name: William HaseldinePepys
persons.description: Pepys was a surgical and scientific instrument maker and chemist. Constructed large batteries used by Davy (amongst others). FRSL.

persons.name: ThomasLawrence
persons.description: Prominent portrait painter and President of the Royal Academy, 1820-1830. Painted the famous portrait of Davy as President of the Royal Society of London. FRSL.

persons.name: George GordonByron
persons.description: From 1798 6th Lord Byron. Famous poet who knew both Humphry and Jane Davy in London and Italy; he wrote a slightly risqué skit on their marriage in 1812. FRSL.

persons.description: Hungarian prince and patron of the arts, especially music. Davy presented him with a copy of Salmonia.

persons.name: JohnMurray
persons.description: Publisher of many of the key literary and scientific texts of the time, including by Byron, Austen, Davy. Published The Quarterly Journal of Science (closely likned to the Royal Institution) as well as Davy's Six Discourses (1827), Salmonia (1828) and Consolations in Travel (1830).

persons.name: JaneDavy
persons.description: Daughter of Charles Kerr, an Antiguan merchant who made his fortune in highly dubious circumstances. Following his death she moved to Britain where she married Schukbrugh Apreece who died in 1807. After running a successful literary salon in Edinburgh she moved to London where she met Davy and they married on 11 April 1812 two days after he had been knighted by the Prince Regent.

persons.name: Aristotle
persons.description: A pupil of Plato's whose philosophical idealism he came to reject, arguing instead for the primacy of observations of natural phenomena. He thus established the divide between theory and experiment in science that can still be detected today. Aristotle's writings became the main way the natural world was understood from the Middle Ages to the seventeenth century, especially in the universities.

persons.name: John JamesTobin
persons.description: Son of Davy's old friend James Webbe Tobin, he trained as a physician before accompanying Davy in 1828 and 1829 as his companion, secretary, and amanuensis during his tour of Italy and the Alps. Davy's name for Tobin was Wildeman or 'wild man'.

persons.description: French chemist, physician and industrialist. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Pierre-SimonLaplace
persons.description: French mathematician seen as the Newton of France. He met Davy in 1813 and 1820. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Claude LouisBerthollet
persons.description: French Chemist. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: JamesWatt
persons.description: A Scottish scientific instrument maker who studied with the chemist Joseph Black at Glasgow University. He developed the separate condenser for steam engines which increased their effieciency significantly. He took out a twenty-five-year patent (ending in 1800) and moved to Birmingham where he went into partnership with the businessman and industrialist Matthew Boulton. They made their fortune by having an effective monopoly of manufacturing steam engines. A friend of Thomas Beddoes, he met Davy on a number of occasions and Davy gave the oration at the unveiling of Watt's statue in Greenock. FRSL.

persons.name: Caroline
persons.description: Of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel who in 1795 married the Prince of Wales (later Prince Regent and George IV. They soon separated causing a series of scandals that lasted until her death. The Davys tended to take her side.

persons.name: DaviesGiddy
persons.description: Changed his surname to Gilbert in 1817. A member of the West Cornwall gentry, he was one of Davy's earliest patrons. A former student of Beddoes at Oxford University, he was a key figure in securing Davy's appointment in 1798 to the Medical Pneumatic Institution. He maintained contact with Davy throughout his life and following his death suceeded Davy as President of the Royal Society of London. FRSL.

persons.description: French chemist and revolutionary politician who is credited with producing the first systematic method of chemical nomenclature. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: HeinrichOlbers
persons.description: Astronomer who worked in Bremen. He specialised in the detection of asteroids and propounded his eponymous paradox. Davy met him on a visit to Bremen in 1824. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: FrancisHome
persons.description: Physician and Professor of Materia Medica at the University of Edinburgh, 1768-1798.

persons.name: CharlesHatchett
persons.description: He made his money from coach building which he used to pursue his interests in chemistry and mineralogy in the course of which he isolated the chemical element now called niobium. He was a Manager of the Royal Institution, playing a key role especially in running its lecture programme during the 1800s. FRSL.

persons.name: Heinrich ChristianSchumacher
persons.description: Founder and Directort of the Altona astronomical observatory. Davy met him during a visit to Bremen in 1824. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Edward CharlesHoward
persons.description: A brother of the Duke of Norfolk, he became a chemist, discovering the explosive properties of mercury fulminate. FRSL

persons.name: GeorgesCuvier
persons.description: French naturalist and zoologist who was one of the founders of palaeontology. Perpetual Secretary of the first class of the Institut de France (Académie des Sciences), Davy met him when in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Francis LeggattChantrey
persons.description: Prominent English sculptor who, at the request of Lady Davy, made the memorial plaque to Davy placed in Westminster Abbey. FRSL.

persons.name: WilliamAllen
persons.description: Allen was a Quaker who worked in the pharmaceutical industry. Davy asked him to give lectures on natural philosophy at the RI. FRSL.

persons.name: WilliamHiggins
persons.description: Nephew of Bryan Higgins. Professor of Chemistry at the Dublin Society where he proposed a theory of chemical atomism. Met Davy in London who supported Higgins's claim to the atomic theory over that of John Dalton. FRSL.

persons.name: Gaspard deProny
persons.description: French mathematician and engineer. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Miltiades
persons.description: Greek Athenian citizen known mostly for his role in the Battle of Marathon.

persons.name: Michel EugèneChevreul
persons.description: French organic chemist. Met Davy when he was in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: MattthewBoulton
persons.description: Birmingham businessman and industrialist who went into partnership with James Watt to manufacture efficient steam engines using Watt's patent for the separate condenser. They made their fortune by having an effective monopoly of manufacturing steam engines until the patent expired in 1800. An early Proprietor of the Royal Institution, he had grave doubts about Rumford's proposal to freely display inventions there. FRSL.

persons.name: André-MarieAmpère
persons.description: French physicist and mathematician and one of the key figure in the early study of electro-magnetism. Davy met him in Paris in 1813 and they developed a scientific rivalry. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Pierre LouisDulong
persons.description: French physicist and chemist who worked mostly on specific heats, but also discovered nitrogen chloride around the same time as Davy. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: ThomasBeddoes
persons.description: A politically radical (Jacobin) chemist and physician who in the 1790s established the Medical Pneumatic Institution in Bristol to investigate the physiological and possible curative effects of all the gases discovered during the eighteenth century. Between late 1798 and early 1801 he employed Davy as Superintendent of the Institution.

persons.name: RichardKirwan
persons.description: Irish chemist, mineralogist and geologist who accused fellow geologist, James Hutton, of athiesm following publication of his Theory of the Earth (1788). FRSL

persons.name: JohnPlayfair
persons.description: Professor of Natural Philosophy at Edinburgh University. His Illustrations of the Huttonian Theory of the Earth (1802) gave strong support to James Hutton's theory of uniformitarianism. FRSL.

persons.name: TeodoroMonticelli
persons.description: Neapolitan naturalist with an interest in volcanology and the mineralogy of Vesuvius. One of Davy's closest contacts in Naples.

persons.name: Samuel TaylorColeridge
persons.description: Poet and philosopher who met Davy while in Bristol with whom he became a close friend. Suggested that if Davy had not been the first chemist of the age, would have been the first poet.

persons.name: Thomas CharlesHope
persons.description: Professor of Medicine and Chemistry at Edinburgh University. Discovered the element strontium and seems to have played a role in Davy's appointment to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

persons.name: CharlesBlagden
persons.description: Physician who kept a revealing diary for most of his life. A friend of Joseph Banks serving as a Secretary of the Royal Society of London, 1784-1797; Knighted 1792. FRSL

persons.name: WilliamBuckland
persons.description: Anglican priest who was later Dean of Westminster. Perhaps the last serious geologist to attempt the reconciliation of the findings of contemporary geology with the Biblical accounts. FRSL.

persons.name: JamesHall
persons.description: Scottish baronet (1776) and MP. Chemist and geologist who supported of James Hutton's theories of uniformitarian geology. FRSL.

persons.name: Carl FriedrichGauss
persons.description: Prominent Hanoverian mathematician who was Director of the observatory at Gottingen University. Davy met him during a visit to Bremen in 1824. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: JosephBanks
persons.description: A member of the Lincolnshire gentry, Banks sailed as a botanist on James Cook's first voyage to the Pacific (1768-1771). Elected President of the Royal Society of London in 1778 he served for forty-two years until just before his death. The dominant figure in the running of English science during that time, he became one of Davy's patrons and ultimately Davy succeeded him to the Presidency. FRSL.

persons.name: HenryCavendish
persons.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

persons.name: NevilMaskelyne
persons.description: Astronomer Royal and a Commissioner of the Board of Longitude. Contributed to scientifically measuring the density of the Earth. FRSL.

persons.name: AntonioCanova
persons.description: Italian sculptor and friend of the Davys.

persons.name: RobertSouthey
persons.description: Poet who met Davy in Bristol and included some of his poems in Annual Anthology. Poet Laureate from 1813 until death.

persons.name: BryanHiggins
persons.description: Irish chemist and natural philosopher who developed a form of the atomic theory of matter. Worked in London, St Petersburg and Jamacia. Uncle of William Higgins.

persons.name: George IV
persons.description: Eldest son of George III and Prince of Wales. Served as Prince Regent during the King's madness, 1811-1820, thereafter King of England, Scotland and Ireland. A major patron of the arts, he personally commanded Davy to go to Naples to oversee the unrolling of the Herculaneum papyri. PatronRSL.

persons.name: SmithsonTennant
persons.description: Tennant was a botanist and chemist and knew Davy through agricultural improvements. Appointed Professor of Chemistry at Cambridge University in 1813, he was killed in a riding accident on France. FRSL.

persons.name: WilliamWordsworth
persons.description: English poet who, with Samuel Taylor Coleridge, published Lyrical Ballads. Davy contributed to seeing the second edition (1800) through the press in Bristol. Poet Laureate from 1843.

persons.name: Louis NicolasVauquelin
persons.description: French pharmacist and chemist who met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: William HydeWollaston
persons.description: Originally a physician he became a prominent chemist, physicist and physiologist isolating the chemical elements osmium, palladium and rhodium. He made his fortune by developing a method of obtaining metallic platinum. A friend and to some extent a rival of Davy's, in 1820 he served briefly as President of the Royal Society of London between Banks's death and Davy's election. FRSL.

persons.name: GeorgeKnox
persons.description: Irish politician who sat in the Dublin and then Westminster parliaments. A collector of minerals, it is not known how he came to know Davy. FRSL.

persons.name: William HaseldinePepys
persons.description: Pepys was a surgical and scientific instrument maker and chemist. Constructed large batteries used by Davy (amongst others). FRSL.

persons.name: ThomasLawrence
persons.description: Prominent portrait painter and President of the Royal Academy, 1820-1830. Painted the famous portrait of Davy as President of the Royal Society of London. FRSL.

persons.name: George GordonByron
persons.description: From 1798 6th Lord Byron. Famous poet who knew both Humphry and Jane Davy in London and Italy; he wrote a slightly risqué skit on their marriage in 1812. FRSL.

persons.name: BenjaminThompson
persons.description: Born in Massachusetts, he served in the British and Bavarian armies. Knighted by George III in 1787, the Elector of Bavaria created him Reichsgraf von Rumford of the Holy Roman Empire in 1792. His appointment in the late 1790s as Bavarian ambassador to London created a minor diplomatic incident, during which he helped establish and manage the Royal Institution, in the course of which he appointed Davy to lecture there. Later he married Lavoisier's widow and lived unhappily ever after. FRSL.

persons.name: WilliamBabington
persons.description: Physician to Guy's Hospital and mineralogist, one of the founders of the Geological Society. A close friend of Davy, Babington was one of those who treated him during his severe illness of late 1807, early 1808. Shared his enthusiasm for angling. FRSL.

persons.name: MatthewBaillie
persons.description: Physician and brother of Joanna Baillie. One of the doctors who saw Davy during his serious illness from late 1807 to early 1808. FRSL.

persons.name: JosephPriestley
persons.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

persons.name: Alexander John GaspardMarcet
persons.description: Genevean-born physician who settled in London and lectured on chemistry at Guy's Hospital. A friend of Davy's. FRSL.

persons.name: JamesWoodhouse
persons.description: Physician and professor of chemistry at University of Pennslyvania from 1795. Visited London in 1802 where he met Davy and later repeated his experiments on nitrous oxide.

persons.name: EdwardJenner
persons.description: Lived in Berkeley, Gloucestershire, where he pioneered vacination, especially for smallpox. FRSL.

persons.name: André-MarieAmpère
persons.description: French physicist and mathematician and one of the key figure in the early study of electro-magnetism. Davy met him in Paris in 1813 and they developed a scientific rivalry. ForMemRSL.

persons.description: Headmaster of Truro Grammar School where Davy was a pupil during 1793.

persons.description: French mathematician seen as the Newton of France. He met Davy in 1813 and 1820. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
persons.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Claude LouisBerthollet
persons.description: French Chemist. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Jean-AntoineChaptal
persons.description: French chemist, physician and industrialist. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Claude LouisBerthollet
persons.description: French Chemist. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: AlessandroVolta
persons.description: Professor of experimental physics at the University of Pavia. At the end of the eighteenth century he Invented the Voltaic pile which produced electric current and which Davy shortly dubbed the battery. Davy described meeting him in 1814 in notebook 14/I, p.38. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: GuiseppePiazzi
persons.description: Professor of astronomy at the University of Palermo. Discovered the first asteroid, which he named Ceres, in 1801. ForMemRSL

persons.name: Domenico LinoMorichini
persons.description: Italian physican and chemist. Professor of Chemistry at the Univerity of Rome from 1798 to his death. Gave Davy medical advice in his final years. ForMemRSL.

places.description: The capital of Italy.

persons.name: Joseph LouisGay-Lussac
persons.description: French chemist and physicist, known mostly for his discovery that water is made of two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen by volume (with Alexander von Humboldt), for two laws related to gases, and for his work on alcohol-water mixtures. Became involved in controversies with Davy over various chemical discoveries. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Louis JacquesThénard
persons.description: Held chairs of chemistry at the Collège de France and the Ecole Polytechnique. Worked closely with Gay-Lussac and met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Domenico LinoMorichini
persons.description: Italian physican and chemist. Professor of Chemistry at the Univerity of Rome from 1798 to his death. Gave Davy medical advice in his final years. ForMemRSL.

Became involved in controversies with Davy over various chemical discoveries. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Jean-BaptisteBiot
persons.description: French mathematician, physicist and astronomer; Professor of Physics at the Collège de France. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Dominique François JeanArago
persons.description: French mathematician, physicist, astronomer and political liberal. Davy presented him with the Copley Medal in 1825. ForMemRSL.

persons.description: A member of the Lincolnshire gentry, Banks sailed as a botanist on James Cook's first voyage to the Pacific (1768-1771). Elected President of the Royal Society of London in 1778 he served for forty-two years until just before his death. The dominant figure in the running of English science during that time, he became one of Davy's patrons and ultimately Davy succeeded him to the Presidency. FRSL.

persons.name: Daniel CarlssonSolander
persons.description: Swedish-born naturalist who worked at the British Museum cataloguing their natural history collections according to the Linnean system. Close to Banks, he accompanied him on various vayages including the Endeavour expedition to the Pacific. FRSL.

persons.name: HenryCavendish
persons.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

persons.name: JohnDavy
persons.description: Humphry Davy's brother, born in Penzance. Spent some time working with Davy in the Royal Institution before studying medicine at Edinburgh University. Appointed an Army physician he was elevated to the rank of Inspector General of Army Hospitals in the West Indies. Following his brother's death, Davy's notebooks came into his possession which he used in writing biographical studies that strongly defended his reputation. FRSL.
